title: AB 100
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The State of California is committed to providing excellent educational opportunities to all pupils, including those who speak languages other than English. Academic research shows the importance of culturally relevant curriculum, with ethnic studies benefiting pupils by increasing academic engagement, test performance, graduation rates, and personal empowerment. The State of California is dedicated to offering quality education to all students, regardless of background. This includes implementing ethnic studies courses in the curriculum to promote inclusivity, close achievement gaps, and increase graduation rates. The State of California is committed to providing quality education for all students, including ethnic studies courses to promote inclusivity and improve graduation rates. The state supports recruiting and retaining teachers with relevant experience in ethnic studies. The Superintendent will oversee the development of a model curriculum in partnership with universities offering ethnic studies programs. The Instructional Quality Commission will assist in developing the curriculum by the 2017-18 school year. Beginning the school year following the adoption of the model curriculum, each school district in California maintaining grade 9 must offer an elective course in ethnic studies to all qualified pupils. If the Commission on State Mandates determines that this act imposes state-mandated costs, reimbursement to local agencies and school districts will be provided. California's laws have a significant impact globally due to its large economy. California's statutory framework and legal structures have a national and global impact due to its economic leadership. Rapid technological advancements require new public policy development. State government officials need to make informed decisions on complex legal issues. California's surplus of law school graduates could benefit the state government. Only 5% of attorneys nationwide work for state governments, limiting the benefit of their expertise. The State of California aims to encourage attorneys to enter public service through a law fellowship program to fill vacancies as older attorneys retire. The California Law Fellowship Program offers limited-term placements in public sector positions within state government for licensed attorneys and qualifying law school graduates. The California Law Fellowship Program aims to provide post-graduate legal experience in the public sector and encourages participants to seek permanent public-sector employment. The University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law administers the program, managing funding and applications. The California Law Fellowship Program is administered by the University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law, managing funding and applications. Participation in the program by attorneys or qualifying law school graduates with state agencies is not considered a gift of public money or value. The California Law Fellowship Program, established by the University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law, provides public benefits to the Legislature. State funds are not used for program administration. Participants are California Law Fellows, and qualifying law school graduates are recipients of ABA-accredited law degrees. The California Law Fellowship Program, established by the University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law, provides public benefits to the Legislature through authorized placements of California Law Fellows. These fellows are not considered employees of the Legislature and their services are not seen as compensation, rewards, or gifts to legislators. Authorization for placement is granted by the Senate Committee on Rules, the Assembly Committee on Rules, or the Joint Committee on Rules. The California Law Fellow is selected based on approved criteria by the Senate Committee on Rules, the Assembly Committee on Rules, or the Joint Committee on Rules. They are bound by an agreement to abide by standards of conduct and other requirements specified by the committees.
